prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the detection of PG1004+130's outflow in absorption, in CO(0-1), we request observations of 1.0 mJy rms noise in order to detect (at a 3 sigma level) lines from clouds that obscure a fraction as low as 10% of their background continuum (at 30 mJy). We intend to bin these data to 10 km/s velocity bins, which would enable us to detect individual clouds or small ensembles of clouds in absorption.

The CO(2-1) flux was found by Bertram et al. (2007) to be 27 mJy.
To compute the 1sigma sensitivity level that our observations need to reach, we request the detection of an outflow whose 3 sigma emission is ten times lower than the ambient medium emission (when integrated over an identical velocity range). For this line, it corresponds to 27/(10.*3) mJy = 0.9 mJy. The use of a velocity bin of 30 km/s, which suffices for the outflow detection, defines the exposure time.
We request the highest possible spatial resolution that will enable us to constrain the radial extent of an unresolved outflow to 220 pc. Based on HST imaging, this source's extent is ~3"

The CO(1-0) flux was estimated from the Gao & Solomon (2004) relation, when assigning half of the infrared luminosity of this source to the starburst. Based on IRAS and Spitzer data, L_IR/2 is 8e11 L_sun. The L'[C0(1-0)] from the Gao & Solomon relation was converted to S_CO as in Solomon et al. (1997). S_CO(1-0) was then converted to S_CO(3-2), using a Milky Way SLED (from Fixsen et al. 1999), i.e, a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) intensity ratio of 2.5. This led to a predicted CO(3-2) line flux of 18mJy.
To compute the 1 sigma sensitivity level that our observations need to reach, we request, like before, the detection of an outflow whose 3 sigma emission is ten times lower than the ambient medium emission (when integrated over an identical velocity range). For this line, it corresponds to 18/(10.*3) mJy = 0.6 mJy. The use of a velocity bin of 30 km/s, which suffices for the outflow detection, defines the exposure time
We request the highest possible spatial resolution that will enable us to constrain the radial extent of an unresolved outflow to 570 pc. Based on HST imaging, this source's extent is constrained to <3"

The CO(1-0) flux was estimated from the Gao & Solomon (2004) relation, when assigning half of the infrared luminosity of this source to the starburst. Based on IRAS and ISO data, L_IR/2 is 1.5e11 L_sun. The L'[C0(1-0)] from the Gao & Solomon relation was converted to S_CO as in Solomon et al. (1997). S_CO(1-0) was then converted to S_CO(3-2), using a Milky Way SLED (from Fixsen et al. 1999), i.e, a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) intensity ratio of 2.5. This led to a predicted CO(3-2) line flux of 19mJy.
To compute the 1 sigma sensitivity level that our observations need to reach, we request, like before, the detection of an outflow whose 3 sigma emission is ten times lower than the ambient medium emission (when integrated over an identical velocity range). For this line, it corresponds to 19/(10.*3) mJy = 0.6 mJy. The use of a velocity bin of 30 km/s, which suffices for the outflow detection, defines the exposure time
We request the highest possible spatial resolution that will enable us to constrain the radial extent of an unresolved outflow to 320 pc. Based on HST imaging, this source's extent is constrained to 2"

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With terminal velocities of 1000-10000 km/s, the ionized gas outflows in broad absorption line (BAL) QSOs could constitute a source of high ram pressure that could accelerate molecular gas to high velocities.We request CO(1-0), (2-1) or (3-2) data of 3 z<0.25 BAL QSOs, analogues of many high-z systems, to test if BAL QSOs could be hosting outflows that are most efficient in expelling molecular gas out of galaxies. We specifically aim to (i) detect new massive outflows, (ii) compare the mass, V, and mass flow rate of the ionized atomic vs. molecular gas in these flows, (iii) determine the momentum transfer efficiency from one phase to the other, (iv) identify the phase that contributes the most to the star formation suppression via mass expulsion. To achieve a high sensitivity for the outflow detection in emission, we will observe CO (2-1) or (3-2) lines, which will probe 2x10^7-5x10^7 M_sun flows in PG1126-041 and PG1416-129. Thanks to a synchrotron mm continuum, the outflow detection in our 3rd target, PG1004+130, can be achieved either through CO(3-2) emission or CO(0-1) absorption. We request 3.7 hrs for a study that will serve as pilot for high-momentum outflows in high-z QSOs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Does the CO excitation in an outflow differ from that in the ambient medium? Insights from 4C12.50

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Computational Sciences, University of Tsukuba
